content: click 'account settings' and then 'composition&addressing' - there are a few options there to set, one for including the original post, another for where to put your reply, and a third on where to put your sig, if desired.

content:
The fact your source is showing Microsoft office objects. I really think the problem is in the email you are trying to edit for brevity. That does not mean don't file a bug. It means it will probably get a lower priority.

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/home
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Do you have the requisite information for the account, such as server names, port, security settings, etc.? Are you receiving error messages. Please share more info before anyone can reply.
creator: davidsk

content:
Doing something multiple times is not going to change what happens.

You say you saw a post about server settings. There is only one canonical source of this information. The mail provider as they are he ones that set up the server. In the case of a university account, you probably should be looking on their IT department web page. You don't mention where you attend so I certainly can not take a peek.

Generally these days the authentication method for all office365 is oauth. Mostly other authentication methods do not work, and all of this predicated the server admin is allowing IMAP and SMTP on the exchange server your account is on. Does your university allow IMAP and SMTP?

If not you will probably need to use the OWL add-on to make use of Exchange Web Services.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Have you tried power cycling your system and modem? It is tried but true when electrical things mess up.

content: This doesn't seem to be a problem with VPN. I just noticed it after the VPN installation. The problem is with Thunderbird and restarting it only works with a reboot. Workaround don't close Thunderbird!

content:
Starting thunderbird should not be affected by a VPN, nor Firefox.

Try starting Thunderbird

  • in troubleshoot mode https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird
  • or offline using command line "--offline" switch

My guess is the server should be smtp.office365.com, but there may be more after seeing the details.

content: That donation is not a requirement, just a suggestion. You can ignore it if desired. We rely on donations, but many ignore it. Thunderbird is still fully usable and you can read and write messages regardless. Are you receiving error messages?
creator: davidsk

content: Have you tried highlighting account in left side of main view, rightclicking and selecting 'subscribe'? That is often the issue. If not, more info may be needed.
creator: davidsk

content: This is how I do that: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - exit thunderbird - click Mail folder and then copy 'local folder to the other drive - restart thunderbird, - click 'account settings' and scroll down to localfolders and click browse button at bottom of pane and change to point to your local folder on the external drive. This may require restarting thunderbird. - on restart, verify that all your folders are there. then you can remove the entries that you copied in earlier step from the C drive. - from here on, your local folders will be on the other drive. Keep that in mind when doing backups.
creator: davidsk
